name: Caffè Rosati
desc:
Like the Caffè Canova, or the restaurants Il Bolognese and Beltrame, the Caffè Rosati was, in the 1950s, one of the emblematic sites of Roman intellectual life. There, after theatre premieres, coming out of screenings of films by Vittorio De Sica or Roberto Rossellini, gathered what the Italian capital counted in the way of artists and thinkers. There, Pasolini joined, amongst others, his friends Laura Betti, Elsa Morante, Alberto Moravia, Giorgio Bassani, Carmelo Bene, Bernardo Bertolucci or even Italo Calvino, for nights of passionate discussions.

Here [at the Caffè Rosati] in the Fifties, Pier Paolo Pasolini and Elsa Morante met, as well as so many young painters and filmmakers, all immersed in a climate of cultural vivacity that, only with the passage of years, do I begin to fully appreciate...
Ugo Pirro, scriptwriter of Pietro Germi's Investigation of a Citizen above Suspicion and Vittorio de Sica's The Garden of the Finzi-Continis
